hints.content:
Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.

We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the parts of the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

Let's take a look at how Jana broke apart the numbers to multiply.

options.explanation:
$54\times 26$

We can break apart $54$ into $50 + 4$ and break apart $26$ into $20+6$.

[[☃ image 1]]

We can start by multiplying $50\times 20$ , $50\times 6$, $4\times 20$ or $4\times6 $. The order does not matter since we will be adding all the products together.

$\begin{array}{rr}
&\begin{align}
54&\\
\underline{{} \times 26}\end{align}\\
\text{any order}&\left\{\begin{align}
1{,}000\\
300\\
80\\
\underline{{}+24}\end{align}\right.\\
&\begin{align}
1{,}404
\end{align}
\end{array}$
options.showPrompt: Can you show me an example please?

options.alt: A rectangular array split in 4 parts. The top left part has a height of 6 and a base of 50. The top right part has a height of 6 and a base of 4. The bottom left part has a height of 20 and a base of 50. The bottom right part has a height of 20 and a base of 4. The left side of the array is labeled 6 plus 20. The bottom of the array is labeled 50 plus 4.

hints.content:
###Step $1$

$\begin{align}
7\blueE{5}&\\
\underline{{} \times 6\blueE{2}}&\\
\blueE{10}&\quad \blueE{2} \times \blueE{5}
\end{align}$

There are $2$ ones in $62$, and there are $5$ ones in $75$.  Also,
$\blueE2\times\blueE5=\blueE{10}$, so Jana did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$

$\begin{align}
\tealE{7}5&\\
\underline{{} \times 6\tealE{2}}&\\
{10}&\quad {2} \times {5}\\
\tealE{140}&\quad \tealE{2} \times \tealE{70}
\end{align}$

There are $2$ ones in $62$, and there are $7$ tens in $75$.  Also,
$\tealE2\times\tealE{70}=\tealE{140}$, so Jana did not make a mistake in step $2$.

###Step $3$

$\begin{align}
7\maroonE{5}&\\
\underline{{} \times \maroonE6{2}}&\\
{10}&\quad {2} \times {5}\\
{140}&\quad {2} \times{70} \\
{\maroonE{300}}&\quad {\maroonE{60}} \times\maroonE{5}
\end{align}$

There are $6$ tens in $62$, and there are $5$ ones in $75$.  Also,
$\maroonE{60}\times\maroonE{5}=\maroonE{300}$, so Jana did not make a mistake in step $3$.

###Step $4$

$\begin{align}
\goldE{7}{5}&\\
\underline{{} \times \goldE{6}{2}}&\\
{10}&\quad {2} \times {5}\\
{140}&\quad {2} \times{70} \\
{{300}}&\quad {60} \times{5} \\
\underline{~~~\goldE{4{,}200}}&\quad {\goldE{60}} \times\goldE{70} \\
\end{align}$

Jana said that $\goldE{60}\times\goldE{70}$ equals $420$, so Jana made a make a mistake in step $4$.
Jana made a mistake in step $4$.

question.content:
Jana tried to evaluate $75\times62$ using partial products, but she made a mistake.  Her work is below.

$\begin{array}{llrr}
&&75 \\
&&\underline{{}\times62} \\
&\blueE{\text{Step 1}}&\blueE{10}& \blueE{2\times5}\\
&\tealE{\text{Step 2}}&\tealE{140}& \tealE{2\times 70}\\
&\maroonE{\text{Step 3}}&\maroonE{300}& \maroonE{60\times 5}\\
&\goldE{\text{Step 4}}&\underline{{}+\goldE{ 420}}& \goldE{60\times 70}\\
&\purpleE{\text{Step 5}}&\purpleE{870}&
 \end{array}$

**Find Jana's mistake.**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue:
There are $2$ ones in $62$, and there are $5$ ones in $75$.  Also,
$\blueE2\times\blueE5=\blueE{10}$, so Jana did not make a mistake in step $1$.

There are $2$ ones in $62$, and there are $7$ tens in $75$.  Also,
$\tealE2\times\tealE{70}=\tealE{140}$, so Jana did not make a mistake in step $2$.

There are $6$ tens in $62$, and there are $5$ ones in $75$.  Also,
$\maroonE{60}\times\maroonE{5}=\maroonE{300}$, so Jana did not make a mistake in step $3$.
$\goldE{60}\times\goldE{70}=4{,}200$, not $420$. So Jana made a mistake in step $4$.
Jana correctly added her four partial products.
